source.title: Mechanized processing on steep slopes in summer conditions to produce short logs
source.notes: Summer follow-up to the Mackenzie (BC) cable-yard processor study comparing Hyundai 210LC/Waratah 620 and John Deere 892 ELC/Waratah 624 processors with loader support on short-wood decks.

notes: 58.5 hours of work sampling captured loader behaviour across three machines; another loader focused on truck loading.
Loaders spent substantially more time piling processed logs in summer because processors occasionally worked without support (Block 7).

processors.label: Hyundai 210LC + Waratah HTH620
processors.description: Smaller carrier/head combination handling mixed lodgepole pine, spruce, and subalpine fir at Mackenzie (Blocks 1–7)
notes: Shift-level utilisation dropped to 66% in Block 6 when processor waited for yarder production and fire closures shortened shifts.
Non-processing time doubled to ~50% of PMH when the processor had to pile its own logs due to loader downtime (Block 7).

processors.label: John Deere 892 ELC + Waratah HTH624
processors.description: Larger carrier/head combination for heavier stems (>0.8 m³) on the same cable-yarded settings
notes: Detailed timing showed productivity above 60 m³/PMH for stems averaging 0.9 m³, but combined shift-level utilisation settled at 78% because the yarder could not keep up during fire closures.
Loader assistance primarily involved pulling large stems down from high decks so the larger head could grab them without exceeding lateral limits.
